D．upset<br />\r\n<strong>III.</strong><strong>阅读理解</strong> <strong>（共</strong><strong>20</strong><strong>小题，每小题</strong><strong>2</strong><strong>分，满分</strong><strong>40</strong><strong>分）</strong><br />\r\n第一节：阅读下列短文，从每题所给的四个选项（A、B、C、D）中，选出最佳选项，并在答题纸上将该选项标号涂黑。<br />\r\n<strong>A</strong><br />\r\nThe great violinist Isaac Stern was born in 1920 in what is now Ukraine. His parents moved to San Francisco the following year. His mother began teaching him the piano when he was six years old. Later，he began studying music at the San Francisco Conservatory，and he progressed quickly. When he was sixteen，he played with the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra(管弦乐队)．<br />\r\nDuring Word War Two，Stern played for thousands of American soldiers. After the war，he was the first American violinist to perform in concert in the Soviet Union.<br />\r\nStern had a strong connection to Israel. He supported young musicians there. He performed in Israel many times，including during the Persian Gulf War in 1991.<br />\r\nStern also supported artistic development and freedom. He was an adviser when the National Endowment for the Arts was founded.<br />\r\nIn 1979，Isaac Stern visited China. He met with Chinese musicians and students. He taught them about classical(古典的)Western music. His visit was made into a film，which is called &ldquo;From Mao to Mozart：Isaac Stern in China&rdquo;．<br />\r\nStern expressed his opinions about the part that music plays in life. He said，&ldquo;Music makes life better for everyone，especially for children. People need it as much as they need bread.&rdquo;<br />\r\nStern supported and guided younger classical musicians，including violinists Itzhak Perlman and Pinchas Zukerman，cellist Yo&shy;Yo Ma and pianist Yefim Bronfman. Isaac Stern died in 2001.<br />\r\n36．What&rsquo;s the best title for this passage?<br />\r\nA．A Great American Violinist<br />\r\nB．Brief Introduction to the Great Violinist Isaac Stern<br />\r\nC．Music in the Great Violinist Isaac Stern&rsquo;s Life<br />\r\nD．The Importance of Music in Life<br />\r\n37．What do we learn about Isaac Stern from the first paragraph?<br />\r\nA．He spent his childhood in Ukraine.<br />\r\nB．He joined the school orchestra at fifteen.<br />\r\nC．He started to learn the piano before he was ten.<br />\r\nD．He made very slow progress when he started to study music.<br />\r\n38．All of the following performers are mentioned in the passage EXCEPT a________.<br />\r\nA．violinist&nbsp; B．cellist&nbsp; C．pianist&nbsp; D．drummer<br />\r\n39．In Isaac Stern&rsquo;s opinion，music is________.<br />\r\nA．something that people can live without<br />\r\nB．most important to adults<br />\r\nC．very important in people&rsquo;s life<br />\r\nD．more important than anything else<br />\r\n<strong>B</strong><br />\r\n<strong>Kim</strong>：My parents are planning a vacation for our family. Do you have any ideas for a good place to go for family bonding?<br />\r\n<strong>Jenny</strong>：Last summer，I spent a week at Twin Peaks Dude Ranch near Salmon，Idaho，and what a wonderful week it was. The food was excellent. Activities included horse riding，camping，fishing，bird watching and swimming. You can relax in hot water while watching the wildlife go by.In fact，it is a perfect place for families to enjoy.<br />\r\n<strong>Christina</strong>：I think Bermuda is a great place for a family vacation. If you live on the East Coast，it only takes two hours by air. I have stayed at many hotels&mdash;both large and small. My two favorites are the Southampton Princess and the Rosedon Hotel. Bermuda is a place that has great weather from June to September. I have also found it very clean，pretty and friendly.<br />\r\n<strong>Kitty</strong>：Nothing can beat the beach！I love the beach. It&rsquo;s just so relaxing and peaceful. And your kids would have so much to do.<br />\r\n<strong>Jane</strong>：I often feel that Florida is not considered as a good place for vacation. People think of Florida and immediately think of Disneyland and crowds and noise and money flying out of wallets. But there&rsquo;s so much more to Florida than Disneyland. There&rsquo;s something for every family member and age range，such as sports，shopping，nature，beaches，water sports and festivals.<br />\r\n<strong>Grace</strong>：Our family had a very similar(类似的)trip with a camping trailer. We went through Nebraska，South Dakota，Wyoming and Montana，and we had a great time together.<br />\r\n40．What does Kim want to know?<br />\r\nA．Whether it is a good time for a family vacation now.<br />\r\nB．Where to have a good vacation with her family.<br />\r\nC．How to make her parents happier during the vacation.<br />\r\nD．Whether someone wants to go traveling with her.<br />\r\n41．In Jenny&rsquo;s opinion，Twin Peaks Dude Ranch is________.<br />\r\nA．a good place for skating in winter<br />\r\nB．not a good place for people who want to enjoy nice food<br />\r\nC．a good place for families to spend time together<br />\r\nD．the best place for those who like swimming<br />\r\n42．According to Christina，which of the following may NOT be a characteristic of Bermuda?<br />\r\nA．Clean.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B．Expensive.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C．Beautiful.&nbsp; D．Friendly.<br />\r\n43．What can we learn from the passage?<br />\r\nA．Christina often travels with her family.<br />\r\nB．Kitty is still a little girl and she likes the beach.<br />\r\nC．Jane thinks Florida has much more to offer than just Disneyland.<br />\r\n&nbsp;D．Grace went camping with her family last year.<br />\r\n<strong>C</strong><br />\r\nSeveral days ago，I learned that my high school chemistry teacher died earlier this year. <u>This</u> was not surprising because he was really old. What was surprising was that most of his former students went to say goodbye to him. All of us mourned his death as he had encouraged us in a way that no other teacher had been able to. This self&shy;called &ldquo;simple Kansas farmer&rdquo; somehow knew how to leave a mark on his students for the rest of their lives.<br />\r\nI was lucky to have such teachers not only in high school but also in college and medical school. In college，the teacher who I will never forget was a professor of electrical engineering，who taught me to use my reasoning ability to solve problems. I learned that if I did not really understand a problem，I could not find a way to solve it .In medical school，I was lucky enough to study with a professor of physiology who taught me that the search for truth involved careful observations(观察)followed by careful analysis(分析)．All these teachers were helping us in a great way. They knew how to encourage their students to study.<br />\r\nI think this is the same way we should teach medical students now. We should encourage the students to do what they are really interested in，and at the same time，give them free space to think on their own.<br />\r\n44．What does the underlined word &ldquo;this&rdquo; in the first paragraph refer to?<br />\r\nA．That the writer learnt the latest news about his chemistry teacher.<br />\r\nB．That the writer&rsquo;s chemistry teacher died earlier this year.<br />\r\nC．That so many students went to say goodbye to the teacher.<br />\r\nD．That the writer&rsquo;s chemistry teacher died at such a young age.<br />\r\n45．From the passage，we learn that we usually mourn when________.<br />\r\nA．someone gets married&nbsp; B．we feel angry&nbsp;&nbsp; C．someone dies&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D．we are ill<br />\r\n46．How many teachers does the writer mention in this passage in all?<br />\r\nA．One.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B．Two.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C．Three.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D．Four.<br />\r\n47．We learn from the passage that the writer________.<br />\r\nA．loved the chemistry teacher more than any other teacher<br />\r\nB．learned to use his reasoning ability from a professor of physiology<br />\r\nC．feels lucky to have met such good teachers<br />\r\nD．studied physiology in college<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n<strong>D</strong><br />\r\nA woman in Japan who had no home sneaked into a man&rsquo;s house and lived without being noticed in his closet for a year. She was arrested(逮捕)after the man found that his food was disappearing and reported it to the police.<br />\r\nPolice found the 58&shy;year&shy;old woman Thursday hiding in the top part of the man&rsquo;s closet and arrested her for getting in without the owner&rsquo;s permission(允许)，police spokesman Hiroki Itakura from southern Kasuya town said&nbsp; Friday.<br />\r\nThe man had security cameras(监视器)which sent images to his cellphone after becoming confused by food disappearing from his kitchen over the past several months.<br />\r\nOne of the cameras on Thursday caught someone moving inside his home after he had left，so he called the police who at first thought it was a thief. However，when they arrived，they found the door locked and all windows closed.<br />\r\n&ldquo;We searched the house and checked everywhere someone could possibly hide，&rdquo;Itakura said. &ldquo;When we opened the closet，we found the woman curled up(蜷曲)on her side，feeling nervous and frightened.&rdquo;<br />\r\nThe woman told the police that she had no place to live and first sneaked into the man&rsquo;s house about a year ago when he left home without locking the door.<br />\r\n&ldquo;She had moved a mattress into the small closet space and even took showers，&rdquo;Itakura said. He called the woman &ldquo;tidy and clean&rdquo;．<br />\r\n48．What&rsquo;s the best title for this passage?<br />\r\nA．A Japanese woman caught living in a man&rsquo;s closet<br />\r\nB．A woman without home<br />\r\nC．Police arrested a woman on Thursday<br />\r\nD．Please lock the door before leaving your house<br />\r\n49．When someone sneaks into a house，he/she most probably________.<br />\r\nA．is the owner of the house&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B．doesn&#39;t want to be noticed by others<br />\r\nC．lives a very poor life&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D．wants to find some food to eat<br />\r\n50．The police arrested the woman mainly because________.<br />\r\nA．she stole the man&#39;s food&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />\r\nB．she often went into other people&rsquo;s houses<br />\r\nC．she entered the man&#39;s house without permission<br />\r\nD．she didn&#39;t open the door when the police arrived<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n<strong>第二节</strong><strong>(</strong><strong>共</strong><strong>5</strong><strong>小题</strong><strong>;</strong><strong>每小题</strong><strong>2</strong><strong>分，满分</strong><strong>10</strong><strong>分）</strong><br />\r\n根据短文内容，从短文后的选项中选出能填入空白处的最佳选项,并在答题卡上将该项涂黑。选项中有两项为多余选项。<br />\r\nEveryone has feelings of anxiety, nervousness, tension and stress from time to time. Here are a few ways to help us manage them.<br />\r\n51 ______&nbsp; We all think we know how to relax. But calming down in front of the TV or computer isn&#39;t true relaxation. Depending on what you&#39;re watching or doing, it could even make you more nervous. The same is true for alcohol, drugs or tobacco. They may seem to relieve anxiety or stress, but it&#39;s a false state of relaxation that&#39;s only temporary. What the body really needs is a relaxation technique &mdash; like deep breathing, tai chi or yoga &mdash; that has a physical effect on the mind.<br />\r\nGet enough sleep, nutrition and exercise. Get the right amount of sleep for your need 一 not too much or too little. Eat well &mdash; choose fruit，vegetables，low-fat proteins and whole grains for long-term energy instead of the short bursts that come from too much sugar or caffeine. 52&nbsp; ______ In that way，your brain and body can operate at their best.<br />\r\nConnect with others. 53&nbsp; ______ Doing things with those we feel close to deepens our bonds, which allows us to feel happier and less upset about things. If you feel worried or nervous about something，talking about it with someone who listens and cares can help you feel more understood and better able to deal with it. You&#39;ll be reminded that everyone has these feelings sometimes. You&#39;re not alone.<br />\r\n54 ______ &nbsp;Heading out for a walk in the park or a hike in the woods can help anyone feel peaceful. Choose somewhere you feel safe so that you can relax and enjoy your surroundings. Walking or hiking can offer additional benefit or exercise. Invite a friend or two 一 or a family member &mdash; along and enjoy feeling connected to people as well.<br />\r\nThink positively. A great way to keep our minds off the worry track is to focus our thoughts on things that are good, beautiful and positive. 55 _____<br />\r\nA. Spend time with your friends or family.<br />\r\nB. Express yourself to others.<br />\r\nC. Connect with nature.<br />\r\nD. Keep away from stress and anxiety.<br />\r\nE. Allow yourself to dream and wish for -the best.<br />\r\nF. Exercise to send oxygen to every cell in the body.<br />\r\nG. Choose a correct way to relax.<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n<strong>卷</strong><strong>II(</strong><strong>共</strong><strong>35</strong><strong>分</strong><strong>)</strong><br />\r\n<strong>IV.</strong><strong>任务型阅读</strong><strong>（共</strong><strong>10</strong><strong>小题，每小题</strong><strong>1</strong><strong>分，满分</strong><strong>10</strong><strong>分）</strong><br />\r\n请认真阅读下列短文，并根据所读内容在文章后表格中的空格里填入最恰当的单词。<strong>注意：每空格</strong><strong>1</strong><strong>个单词</strong>。<br />\r\nReal policemen hardly recognize any resemblance between their lives and what they see on TV.<br />\r\nThe first difference is that a policeman&rsquo;s real life revolved round criminal law. He has to know exactly what actions are crimes and what evidence can be used to prove them in court. He has to know nearly as much law as a professional lawyer, and what is more, he has to apply it on his feet, in the dark and rain, running down a street after someone he wants to talk to.<br />\r\nLittle of his time is spent in chatting. He will spend most of his working life typing millions of words on thousands of forms about hundreds of sad, unimportant people who are guilty of stupid crimes.<br />\r\nMost television crime drama is about finding the criminal: as soon as he&rsquo;s arrested, the story is over. In real life, finding criminal is seldom much of a problem. Except in very serious cases like murders and terrorist attacks, little effort is spent on searching.<br />\r\nHaving made an arrest, a detective really starts to work. He has to prove his case in court and to do that he often has to gather a lot of different evidence.<br />\r\nA third big difference between the drama detective and the real one is the unpleasant pressures: first, as members of a police force, they always have to behave absolutely in accordance with the law. Secondly, as expensive public servants, they have to get results. They can hardly ever do both. Most of the time, some of them have to break the rules in small ways.<br />\r\nIf the detective has to deceive the world, the world often deceives him. Hardly anyone he meets tells him the truth. And this separation the detective feels between himself and the rest of the world is deepened by the simple-minded &mdash; as he see it &mdash; of citizens, social workers, doctors, law-makers, and judges, who, instead of eliminating crime, punish the criminals less severely in the hope that this will make them reform. The result, detective feel, is that nine-tenths of their work is re-catching people who should have stayed behind bars. This makes them rather cynical(愤世嫉俗的).<br />\r\n&nbsp;</span><br />\r\n<table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\">\r\n	<tbody>\r\n		<tr>\r\n			<td style=\"width: 122px\">\r\n				<span style=\"font-size: 16px\">&nbsp;</span></td>\r\n			<td style=\"width: 249px\">\r\n				<span style=\"font-size: 16px\">Police in 1.________ world</span></td>\r\n			<td style=\"width: 215px\">\r\n				<span style=\"font-size: 16px\">Police on TV</span></td>\r\n		</tr>\r\n		<tr>\r\n			<td style=\"width: 122px; height: 73px\">\r\n				<span style=\"font-size: 16px\">Knowledge of 2.___ law</span></td>\r\n			<td style=\"width: 249px; height: 73px\">\r\n				<span style=\"font-size: 16px\">He has to know as much as a professional lawyer and applies it to their 3.____ work.</span></td>\r\n			<td style=\"width: 215px; height: 73px\">\r\n				<span style=\"font-size: 16px\">There is no 4.________ for them to know about it.</span></td>\r\n		</tr>\r\n		<tr>\r\n			<td style=\"width: 122px; height: 72px\">\r\n				<span style=\"font-size: 16px\">Different 5.________ time spent</span></td>\r\n			<td style=\"width: 249px; height: 72px\">\r\n				<span style=\"font-size: 16px\">He 6.________ most of his working life to collecting and providing evidence needed to prove his case in court.</span></td>\r\n			<td style=\"width: 215px; height: 72px\">\r\n				<span style=\"font-size: 16px\">Time is spent finding criminals. You&#39;ll think again after reading this story.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />\r\nBarbara Ann Kiper hated her feet. They were too big and she always seemed to <u>&nbsp;&nbsp;1&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;over them when someone was<u>&nbsp; 2 </u>&nbsp;usually a smart guy. Come to think of it, her teeth were too big, too. The other kids teased (取笑) her because of the way she<br />\r\n<u>&nbsp;3 </u>&nbsp;, and because she wanted to be a sportswriter someday. No matter what she did, she was teased for being<br />\r\nThat&#39;s <u>&nbsp;&nbsp;5&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;she started writing down things that she liked in a notebook. &quot;It was like a friend, and it&nbsp;&nbsp; <u>6&nbsp;&nbsp; </u>me that there are good things, <u>&nbsp;&nbsp;7&nbsp;&nbsp; </u>everything around me is unpleasant,&#39;&#39; she says. She copied the list over and over, <u>&nbsp;&nbsp;8 </u>&nbsp;&nbsp;new things every day.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />\r\nOne day, she decided to <u>&nbsp;&nbsp;9&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;her list with some of the girls in her class, hoping they would think it was as much fun as she did.&nbsp; But&nbsp; <u>&nbsp;10 </u>&nbsp;, they make her feel stupid again. &quot;They laughed at me,&quot; she remembers, &quot;I was ashamed, and I <u>11</u> dong it.&quot;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />\r\nHere comes the <u>&nbsp;&nbsp;12&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;part. When she was in 10th grade, Kipfer found her old notebook and decided to<u>&nbsp;&nbsp; 13&nbsp; </u>where she left off. &quot;It was like a diary, like a photograph of my life,&quot; she says. She started writing to publishers, asking them if they&#39;d be interested in printing her list as a book.<br />\r\nShe kept writing to one company <u>&nbsp;&nbsp;14&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;&nbsp;, because she liked the types of books it printed. &quot;He kept saying, &#39;It&#39;s just a list, what am I supposed to do with it? ..... You&#39;re not <u>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;15&nbsp; </u>to do anything with it. It&#39;s&nbsp;&nbsp; <u>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;16&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;supposed to remind people of something they did that was really <u>&nbsp;&nbsp;17&nbsp; </u>.&quot;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />\r\nFinally, the publisher <u>&nbsp;&nbsp;18&nbsp; </u>to turn Kipfer&#39;s list into a book, which sold more than I million copies! 14,000 Things to Be Happy About even <u>&nbsp;&nbsp;19&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;it to be New York Times Best Sellers list.<u>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 20 </u>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;being a best-selling author, Kipfer also went to realize her dream of becoming a sports editor at the Chicago Tribune.<br />\r\n1. Instead of&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. While&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. Besides<br />\r\n<strong>VIII.</strong><strong>阅读理解（共</strong><strong>5</strong><strong>小题，每小题</strong><strong>2</strong><strong>分，满分</strong><strong>10</strong><strong>分）</strong><br />\r\nThe stereotype (固有观念) of computer scientists as <u>nerds</u> who stay up all night coding and have no social life may be driving women away from the field, according to a new study published this month. This stereotype can be brought to mind based only on the appearance of the environment in a classroom or an office.<br />\r\n&ldquo;When people think of computer science the image that immediately pops into many of their minds is about the computer geek (怪人) surrounded by such things as computer games, science fiction and junk food，&rdquo; said Sapna Cheryan, a university of Washington assistant professor of psychology and the study&#39;s lead author. &ldquo;That stereotype doesn&#39;t appeal to many women who don&#39;t like the portrait of masculinity(男性化)．&rdquo;<br />\r\nCheryan set up four experiments involving more than 250 female and male students who were not studying computer science to look at possible reasons why the proportion of women in the field is dropping while the proportion of women in such disciplines as biology, mathematics and chemistry is increasing.<br />\r\nIn the first experiment, students entered a small classroom that either contained objects stereotypically associated with computer science such as Star Trek posters, video game boxes and Coke cans, or non-stereotypical items such as nature posters, art, a dictionary and coffee cups. The students were told to ignore these objects because the room was being shared with another class. After spending several moments in the classroom, the students filled out questionnaires(调查问卷) that asked about their attitude toward computer science.<br />\r\nWomen exposed to the stereotypical setup expressed less interest in computer science than those who saw the non-stereotypical objects. Men placed in the same situations did not show a similar drop in interest in computer science. Cheryan said this study suggests that a student&#39;s choice of classes or a major can be influenced by the appearance of classrooms, halls and offices.<br />\r\n1. The underlined word &ldquo;nerds&rdquo; in Paragraph 1 probably refers to &ldquo;________&rdquo;．<br />\r\nA. dull persons&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. active persons&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. intelligent persons&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. funny persons<br />\r\n2. Women are less likely to choose computer science because ________.<br />\r\nA. it is too difficult for them&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;B. they have wrong understanding of it<br />\r\nC. the lifestyle of computer scientists turns them away&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />\r\nD. they don&#39;t like the social life of computer scientists<br />\r\n3. A woman would probably lose interest in computer science when she sees a ________.<br />\r\nA. Star Trek poster&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. nature poster&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. dictionary&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. coffee cup<br />\r\n4. What can influence a woman&#39;s choice of classes, according to the passage?<br />\r\nA. The contents of computer science.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. The space in the classroom.<br />\r\nC. The number of students in the classroom.&nbsp;&nbsp; D. The classroom environment.<br />\r\n5. According to the experiment, women are more likely to choose computer science if ________.<br />\r\nA. it is made more lively and interesting&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />\r\nB. they are exposed to the stereotypical setup<br />\r\nC. they see the non-stereotypical objects in the classroom&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />\r\nD. they are allowed to learn it without men<br />\r\n&nbsp;</span><br />\r\n','','','221.1.213.194');

A. cleaned&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. wiped&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. cleared&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. felt<br />\r\n<strong>III.</strong><strong>阅读理解</strong> <strong>（共</strong><strong>20</strong><strong>小题，每小题</strong><strong>2</strong><strong>分，满分</strong><strong>40</strong><strong>分）</strong><br />\r\n<strong>第一节：阅读下列短文，从每题所给的</strong><strong>A</strong><strong>、</strong><strong>B</strong><strong>、</strong><strong>C</strong><strong>、</strong><strong>D</strong><strong>四个选项中，选出最佳选项，并在答题纸上将该选项涂黑。</strong><br />\r\n<strong>A</strong><br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; When I was growing up in America，I was ashamed of my mother&#39;s Chinese English. Because of her English，she was often treated unfairly. People in department stores，at banks，and at restaurants did not take her seriously，did not give her good service，pretended not to understand her，or even acted as if they did not hear her.<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; My mother has long realized the limitations of her English as well. When I was fifteen，she used to have me call people on the phone to pretend I was she. I was forced to ask for information or even to yell at people who had been rude to her. One time I had to call her stockbroker(股票经纪人)．I said in an adolescent voice that was not very convincing，&ldquo;This is Mrs. Tan.&rdquo;<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; And my mother was standing beside me，whispering loudly，&ldquo;Why he don&#39;t send me check already two weeks late.&rdquo;<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; And then，in perfect English I said，&ldquo;I&#39;m getting rather concerned. You agreed to send the check two weeks ago，but it hasn&#39;t arrived.&rdquo;<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; Then she talked more loudly.&ldquo; What he wants？I come to New York to tell him in front of his boss.&rdquo; And so I turned to the stockbroker again，&ldquo;I can&#39;t tolerate any more excuse. If I don&#39;t receive the check immediately，I am going to have to speak to your manager when I am in New York next week.&rdquo;<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; The next week we ended up in New York. While I was sitting there red-faced，my mother，the real Mrs. Tan，was shouting to his boss in her broken English.<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; When I was a teenager，my mother&#39;s broken English embarrassed me. But now，I see it differently. To me，my mother&#39;s English is perfectly clear，perfectly natural. It is my mother tongue. Her language，as I hear it，is vivid，direct，and full of observation and wisdom. It was the language that helped shape the way I saw things，expressed ideas，and made sense of the world.<br />\r\n36．Why was the author&#39;s mother poorly served?<br />\r\n&nbsp; A．She was unable to speak good English.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B．She was often misunderstood.<br />\r\n&nbsp; C．She was not clearly heard.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D．She was not very polite.<br />\r\n37．From Paragraph 2，we know that the author was ________.<br />\r\n&nbsp; A．good at pretending&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B．rude to the stockbroker<br />\r\n&nbsp; C．ready to help her mother&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D．unwilling to phone for her mother<br />\r\n38．After the author made the phone call，________.<br />\r\n&nbsp; A．they forgave the stockbroker&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B．they failed to get the check<br />\r\n&nbsp; C．they went to New York immediately&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D．they spoke to their boss at once<br />\r\n39．What does the author think of her mother&#39;s English now?<br />\r\n&nbsp; A．It confuses her.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B．It embarrasses her.<br />\r\n&nbsp; C．It helps her understand the world.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D．It helps her tolerate rude people.<br />\r\n<strong>B</strong><br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The common cold is the world&#39;s most widespread illness, which is plagues(疫病) that flesh receives.<br />\r\nThe most widespread mistake of all is that colds are caused by cold. They are not. They are caused by viruses(病毒) passing on from person to person. You catch a cold by coming into contact, directly or indirectly, with someone who already has one. If cold causes colds, it would be reasonable to expect the Eskimos to suffer from them forever. But they do not. And in isolated Arctic regions explorers have reported being free from colds until coming into contact again with infected people from the outside world by way of packages and mail dropped from airplanes.?<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; During the First World War soldiers who spent long periods in the trenches(战壕), cold and wet, showed no increased tendency to catch colds.?<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; In the Second World War prisoners at the notorious Auschwitz concentration camp(奥斯维辛集中营), naked and starving, were astonished to find that they seldom had colds.?<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; At the Common Cold Research Unit in England, volunteers took part in Experiments in which they gave themselves to the discomforts of being cold and wet for long stretches of time. After taking hot baths, they put on bathing suits, allowed themselves to be with cold water, and then stood about dripping wet in drafty room. Some wore wet socks all day while others exercised in the rain until close to exhaustion. Not one of the volunteers came down with a cold unless a cold virus was actually dropped in his nose.?<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; If, then, cold and wet have nothing to do with catching colds, why are they more frequent in the winter? Despite the most pains&mdash;taking research, no one has yet found the answer. One explanation offered by scientists is that people tend to stay together indoors more in cold weather than at other times, and this makes it easier for cold viruses to be passed on.?<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; No one has yet found a cure for the cold. There are drugs and pain suppressors(止痛片) such as aspirin, but all they do is to relieve the symptoms(症状).?<br />\r\n40. The writer offered _______ examples to support his argument.?<br />\r\nA. 4&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. 5&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. 6&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. 3<br />\r\n41. Which of the following does not agree with the chosen passage??<br />\r\nA. The Eskimos do not suffer from colds all the time.?<br />\r\nB. Colds are not caused by cold.?<br />\r\nC. People suffer from colds just because they like to stay indoors.?<br />\r\nD. A person may catch a cold by touching someone who already had one.<br />\r\n42. The passage mainly discusses ________.<br />\r\nA. the experiments on the common cold&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. the fallacy about the common cold?<br />\r\nC. the reason and the way people catch colds&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. the continued spread of common colds<br />\r\nC<br />\r\nAccording to a famous optical(光学) expert, Alexander, who recently visited Shanghai, the developed countries in Europe and America have made rules that children must wear resinous(树脂) glasses instead of the traditional glasses made of glass. This is because the glass glasses are more likely to do harm to children&rsquo;s eyesight.<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; Alexander pointed out: wearing the right glasses as soon as possible is still the best way to cure and put right children&rsquo;s eyesight problems.<br />\r\nIn America and Japan the resinous glasses have taken up 80 percent of the glasses market. And some European countries and America have made it a law that children, teenagers and drivers must wear resinous glasses. Now, about 10 million children in China have different eyesight problems and they need timely treatment.<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; But still, too many parents are buying the traditional glass glasses for their children. This is mainly because many parents know little or nothing about the good points of the resinous glasses. Besides, the price for the new glasses is a little higher than the traditional ones.<br />\r\n44. This news article mainly wants to tell us _______.<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; A. Alexander visited China and introduced a new type of glasses<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. we should wear resinous glasses instead of glass glasses<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. resinous glasses are popular in Europe and America<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. glasses can be made of other materials instead of glass<br />\r\n45. It can be inferred from this news text that _______.<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; A. resinous glasses are not on sale in China yet<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. resinous glasses are not acceptable in China<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. glass glasses have disappeared on western market because there is a law against them<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. glass glasses are the first choice in China not only because of their price<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;D<br />\r\n&nbsp; We spent a day in the country, picking wild flowers. With the car full of flowers we were going home. On our way back my wife noticed a cupboard (柜厨) outside a furniture shop. It was tall and narrow. &ldquo;Buy it, &rdquo; &nbsp;my wife said at once. &ldquo;We&rsquo;ll carry it home on the roof rack. I&rsquo;ve always wanted one like that.&rdquo;<br />\r\n&nbsp; What could I do? Ten minutes later I was ￡20 poorer; and the cupboard was tied on the roof rack. It was six feet long and eighteen inches square, quite heavy too.<br />\r\n&nbsp; In the gathering darkness I drove slowly. Other drivers seemed unusually polite that evening. The police even stopped traffic to let us through. Carrying furniture was a good idea.<br />\r\n&nbsp; After a time my wife said, &ldquo;There&rsquo;s a long line of cars behind. Why don&rsquo;t they overtake, I wonder?&rdquo; In fact a police car did overtake. The two officers inside looked at us seriously as they passed. But then, with great kindness, they led us through the rush-hour traffic. The police car stopped at our village church. One of the officers came to me.<br />\r\n&nbsp; &ldquo;Right, sir, &rdquo; &nbsp;he said. &ldquo;Do you need any more help?&rdquo;<br />\r\n&nbsp; I was a bit puzzled. &ldquo;Thanks, officer, &rdquo; &nbsp;I said. &ldquo;You have been very kind. I live just on the road.&rdquo;<br />\r\n&nbsp; He was staring at our car, first at the flowers, then at the cupboard. &ldquo;Well, well, &rdquo; he said, laughing. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s a cupboard you&rsquo;ve got there! We thought it was something else.&rdquo;<br />\r\nMy wife began to laugh. The truth hit me like a stone between the eyes. I smiled at the officer. &ldquo;Yes, it&rsquo;s a cupboard, but thanks again.&rdquo; I drove home as fast as I could.<br />\r\n47. (There are more headings than paragraphs, so you will not use all of them.)<br />\r\nHollywood movies are regularly filled with sex and violence. They can be exciting films but sometimes all you want is a little light-hearted entertainment.<br />\r\n51.______________<br />\r\nHave you heard of Bollywood? All singing, all dancing and unrealistic, it is the perfect alternative to normal Hollywood movies. Bollywood is the Indian film industry, based in Mumbai, formerly known as Bombay. Most Chinese school kids have probably never seen an Indian film. Yet Bollywood is the largest producer of films in the world. This year the Indian Filmgare Awards, Bollywood&#39;s Oscrs, turn 50 years old.<br />\r\n52.___________<br />\r\nThe typical Bollywood movie usually has the following ingredients: a cup of romance, a tea-spoon of comedy, a dash of international sight-seeing, served with a huge slice of singing and dancing. There will also be one brave hero, one beautiful heroine and one baddie. The result is a fun-filled musical.<br />\r\n53.___________<br />\r\nThere is never any mention of politics, poverty or war. The actors change clothes and locations within a single song. But the audience don&#39;t mind. To Indian movie lovers, especially the poor, such films are a gateway to heaven and the stars are their gods. The films take them to a magical world away from their everyday troubles. The films tell them the impossible is possible and that true love conquers all.<br />\r\n54._____________<br />\r\nBut, behind the beautiful scenes, Bollywood still emphasizes traditional family values. In most films, if two lovers want to break an arranged marriage, they can&#39;t just run away. They must win over their parents.<br />\r\n55.___________<br />\r\nSo if you&#39;re tired of all that Hollywood actions, check out the following Bollywood films. They will take you to a brighter, cheerier and more colourful world, where it&#39;s still cool to dance around a tree and sing a love song.&nbsp;<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n<strong>卷</strong> <strong>II (</strong><strong>共</strong><strong>35</strong><strong>分</strong><strong>)</strong><br />\r\n<strong>IV.</strong><strong>阅读表达（共</strong><strong>5</strong><strong>小题，每小题</strong><strong>2</strong><strong>分，满分</strong><strong>10</strong><strong>分）</strong><br />\r\n[1]Email has become one of the most efficient ways to communicate with people. The problem is that we use it so much that we often misuse it. Some bad habits will affect our ability to communicate properly without our realizing it&#39;s happening. Below，________.<br />\r\n[2]Many people receive dozens of upsetting advertising emails each day. One of the ways we cope with those emails is to glance at the titles of the messages. If it fails to catch our attention, chances are we&#39;ll delete the email. So write a clear title when you send an email.<br />\r\n[3]If there&#39;s one thing that communicating through email has taught us，it is that you can never take back what you have written. When emailing your friends or family or anyone，control your emotions，especially if you&#39;re angry. <u>Sending impolite words o someone might help you get something off your chest, but you will pay for it in the future. </u><br />\r\n[4]Few people enjoy reading long blocks of words，so shorten it and keep it under six or seven sentences. If you must describe every detail of an event，or write an entire chapter to explain something，pick up the phone and call.<br />\r\n[5]It&#39;s important for you to follow the rules of grammar and spelling. The people you&#39;re emailing will appreciate your taking the time to write like an adult. Notes such&nbsp; as &ldquo;r u thr yt？&rdquo; might work well for a 14-year-old who enjoys text messaging，but emailing deserves more respect. Plus，if you&#39;re brief，using the proper grammar and spelling only takes a few seconds.<br />\r\n[6]When you use emails to communicate with the people in your social network，make sure you use it properly. Over time，you&#39;ll discover that your friends and family look forward to reading your messages.<br />\r\n1. List three suggestions made by the author based on the text. Some smoking and alcoholic drinks are an &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(获得的) taste and are not born with.<br />\r\n10. ________________6. accused sb. of_________________</span></li>\r\n</ol>\r\n<ol>\r\n	<li align=\"left\" value=\"7\">\r\n		<span style=\"font-size: 16px\">approved of　&nbsp; ________________ 8.get/be absorbed in ______________</span></li>\r\n</ol>\r\n<ol>\r\n	<li align=\"left\" value=\"9\">\r\n		<span style=\"font-size: 16px\">has a good nose for _____________ 10.keep sth. in mind _______________</span></li>\r\n</ol>\r\n<span style=\"font-size: 16px\">&nbsp;<br />\r\n<strong>III.</strong><strong>选词填空（共</strong><strong>10</strong><strong>小题，每小题</strong><strong>1</strong><strong>分，满分</strong><strong>10</strong><strong>分）</strong><br />\r\n<strong>用所给的词或短语的适当形式填空</strong><br />\r\nconcentrate；inform；meanwhile；accuse； demand；approve; So is mine&nbsp; B.So mine is&nbsp;&nbsp; C.So does mine&nbsp;&nbsp; D.So mine does<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n<strong>VII.</strong><strong>完形填空（共</strong><strong>20</strong><strong>小题，每小题</strong><strong>1</strong><strong>分，满分</strong><strong>20</strong><strong>分）</strong><br />\r\nYears ago，if a teenager had some problems in his life，he might go home and write in his diary；now, a teenager with <u>&nbsp;1&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;problems might go onto the Internet and write about them in a blog（博客）. In many ways, a diary and a blog are very <u>&nbsp;2 </u>. But what makes blogging different from writing in a（n）<u>3 </u>&nbsp;diary?<br />\r\nThe biggest difference is that a blog is much more <u>&nbsp;4&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;than a diary. Usually，a teenager treats his diary like a book full of <u>&nbsp;5 </u>&nbsp;that he does not want to<u> 6 </u>&nbsp;with others.<br />\r\nIt&rsquo;s interesting that someone who writes in a blog <u>&nbsp;7&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;a diary will probably write nearly the same information.<br />\r\nI have a little sister, and sometimes I go online to read her<u> 8</u>. She writes about things like waking up early for swimming practice and not studying enough for her chemistry test.<u> 9&nbsp;&nbsp; </u>I was her age, I wrote about the same thing, but<u> 10&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;in my dairy. Then, after I had finished writing, I would hide my diary in a secret place because I was <u>11&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;that my sister might read it.<br />\r\nThe biggest <u>&nbsp;12&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;with blogging is that anyone can read what you write. If I was angry with a friend during high school and wrote something <u>13&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;about him in my diary, he would never know.<u> 14</u>, if my sister ever wrote something bad about a friend, that friend might <u>15&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </u>her blog and get angry.<br />\r\nThere are also<u> 16 </u>&nbsp;to blogging, of course. If I was feeling sad one day and wrote in my diary, &ldquo;Nobody cares about me ...&rdquo; Because no one would <u>&nbsp;17 </u>&nbsp;about it. However, if my sister wrote the same sentence in her blog, her best friend would quickly <u>18 </u>&nbsp;and tell her how much they<u> 19&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;her. Blog help people<u> 20&nbsp;&nbsp; </u>in contact with their friend and know what the people around them are doing.<br />\r\n1. A. the same&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. interesting&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;C. difficult &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;D. daily<br />\r\n2. A. simple&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;B. special&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. similar&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;D. different<br />\r\n3. A. persona&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. ordinary&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;C. meaningful&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. traditional<br />\r\n4. A. thoughts&nbsp;&nbsp; B. puzzles&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;C. ideas &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;D. secrets<br />\r\n6. A. tell&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. share&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. publish &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;D. solve<br />\r\n7. A. instead of&nbsp;&nbsp; B. as well as&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;C. except for&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. besides<br />\r\n8. A. blog&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. diary&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;C. report&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. web<br />\r\n9. A. Although&nbsp;&nbsp; B. Since&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. When&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. Because<br />\r\n10. A. only&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. already&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;C. still&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. never<br />\r\n11. A. angry&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. sad&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. glad &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;D. worried<br />\r\n12. A. problem&nbsp;&nbsp; B. doubt&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. question&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. mistake<br />\r\n13. A. boring&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. wrong &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;C. bad &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;D. funny<br />\r\n14. A. So&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. However&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. Therefore&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;D. Then<br />\r\n15. A. steal&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. break&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. write&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. read<br />\r\n16. A. reasons&nbsp;&nbsp; B. wishes&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. shortcomings &nbsp;D. advantages<br />\r\n17. A. care&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. know&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. think&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. ask<br />\r\n18. A. prepare&nbsp;&nbsp; B. begin&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. respond&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. feel<br />\r\n19. A. like&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. miss&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. need&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. stand<br />\r\n20. A. lose&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. stay&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. leave&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. find<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n<strong>VIII.</strong><strong>阅读理解（共</strong><strong>5</strong><strong>小题，每小题</strong><strong>2</strong><strong>分，满分</strong><strong>10</strong><strong>分）</strong><br />\r\nThe common cold is the world&#39;s most widespread illness，which is plagues（疫病）that flesh receives. The most widespread fallacy（谬误） of all is that colds caused by cold. They are not. They are caused by viruses passing on from person to person. You catch a cold by coming into contact，directly or indirectly，with someone who already has one. If cold causes colds，it would be reasonable to expect the Eskimos to suffer from them forever. But they do not. And in isolated arctic regions explorers have reported being free from colds until coming into contact again with infected people from the outside world by way of packages and mail dropped from airplanes. During the First World War soldiers who spent long periods in the trenches（战壕），cold and wet， showed no increased tendency to catch colds. In the Second World War prisoners at the notorious Auschwitz concentration camp（奥斯维辛集中营）, naked and starving, were astonished to find that they seldom had colds. At the Common Cold Research Unit in England， volunteers took part in Experiments in which they gave themselves to the discomforts of being cold and wet for long stretches of time. After taking hot baths， they put on bathing suits， allowed themselves to be with cold water， and then stood about dripping wet in drafty room. Some wore wet socks all day while others exercised in the rain until close to exhaustion. Not one of the volunteers came down with a cold unless a cold virus was actually dropped in his nose. If，then，cold and wet have nothing to do with catching colds，why are they more frequent in the winter？Despite the most pains-taking research，no one has yet found the answer. One explanation offered by scientists is that people tend to stay together indoors more in cold weather than at other times，and this makes it easier for cold viruses to be passed on. No one has yet found a cure for the cold. There are drugs and pain suppressors（止痛片） such as aspirin， but all they do is relieve the symptoms。<br />\r\n1. The writer offered _______ examples to support his argument.<br />\r\n&nbsp;A. 4&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;B. 5 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C. 6 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;D. 3<br />\r\n2. Which of the following does not agree with the chosen passage？<br />\r\n&nbsp;A. The Eskimos do not suffer from colds all the time.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />\r\n&nbsp;B. Colds are not caused by cold.<br />\r\n&nbsp;C. People suffer from colds just because they like to stay indoors.<br />\r\n&nbsp;D. A person may catch a cold by touching someone who already has one.<br />\r\n3. Arctic explorers may catch colds when _______.<br />\r\n&nbsp;A. they are working in the isolated arctic regions&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. they are writing reports in terribly cold weather<br />\r\n&nbsp;C. they are free from work in the isolated arctic regions&nbsp;&nbsp; D. they are coming into touch again with the outside world<br />\r\n4. Volunteers taking part in the experiments in the Common Cold Research Unit _______.<br />\r\n&nbsp;A. suffered a lot&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. never caught colds&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />\r\n&nbsp;C. often caught colds&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. became very strong<br />\r\n5. The passage mainly discusses _______.<br />\r\n&nbsp;A. the experiments on the common cold&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. the fallacy about the common cold<br />\r\n&nbsp;C. the reason and the way people catch colds&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. the continued spread of common colds<br />\r\n&nbsp;</span><br />\r\n','','','221.1.213.194');

Anderson saw the nickel&shy;gray Toyota Camry and used her daughter&rsquo;s key to unlock the car，start the engine and drive home.<br />\r\nWhen Charlie Vansant left class a short time later，he found only an empty parking spot. He first assumed the car had been towed，but when the police couldn&#39;t find a record of it，they took a theft report.<br />\r\nThe morning after Anderson took back the car，her daughter discovered the Camry in the driveway wasn&#39;t hers. She found Vansant&rsquo;s name on paperwork in the glove compartment and looked up his phone number on the Website for the university.<br />\r\nWhen she told Vansant the car was in her driveway，&ldquo;It sounded real fishy at first，like maybe she wanted to hold the thing for ransom，&rdquo;Vansant said!<br />\r\nHe eventually went to the house with a police officer，where he was reunited with his car. According to a police report，the case was closed &ldquo;because of the mistaken car identity.&rdquo; Anderson wasn&#39;t charged.<br />\r\nVansant seemed to blame the car company more than the &ldquo;thief&rdquo;．&ldquo;Her key fit not only my lock，but my ignition as well&mdash;so high&shy;five for Toyota，I guess，&rdquo; he said.<br />\r\nToyota spokesman Bill Kwong said&nbsp; key technology wasn&#39;t as sophisticated as two decades ago，and there were so many ways to cut a key，making it possible for such a mix&shy;up to occur. He said the company now has a microchip embedded(嵌入)in the keys for 90 percent of its vehicles that allows them to start only with the correct key.<br />\r\n36．We can learn from the story that Kate Anderson_____.<br />\r\n&nbsp;A．was an experienced but unlucky thief<br />\r\n&nbsp;B．took Vansant&rsquo;s car away by chance<br />\r\n&nbsp;C.&nbsp; could unlock any car with her special key<br />\r\n&nbsp;D．was accused of theft and put into prison<br />\r\n37．When Charlie Vansant received the phone call，he__________.<br />\r\n&nbsp;A．ran as fast as he could to the police station<br />\r\n&nbsp;B．felt someone was playing a joke on him<br />\r\n&nbsp;C．suspected he would be forced to pay for the car<br />\r\n&nbsp;D．went directly to Anderson and collected his car<br />\r\n38．Who should be responsible for the accident?<br />\r\n&nbsp;A．Toyota Camry.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B．Charlie Vansant.&nbsp; C．Toyota Company.&nbsp; D．The police.<br />\r\n39．According to the passage，it can be learned that_____________.<br />\r\n&nbsp;A．the daughter is more honest than her mother<br />\r\n&nbsp;B．many thefts occurred because the same keys were used<br />\r\n&nbsp;C．Toyota Camry is a kind of car，which is easier to unlock<br />\r\n&nbsp;D．the car producers should pay more attention to car identity<br />\r\n<strong>B</strong><br />\r\nThe laptop is a machine which can be a mobile office；it can be used to entertain us and people can play computer games on them. One machine can perform many tasks at the same time. As technology grows，the size of the new laptop machines is <u>decreasing</u>. Now laptops are lighter，have smaller screen sizes，and perform better. Smaller screen laptops，which are more convenient to take along with，have been specially designed for professionals. Huge display screen laptops are still used by graphic(绘画的)designers and those who like playing computer games.<br />\r\nLaptops are advanced machines，and they can be very expensive. When we spend much money on something，we should take good care of it. I know some people who buy a new laptop every year. The reason they do this is that the old one either is broken or has some problems which cannot be fixed. Common problems are the breaking of the screen，the breaking of joints of the laptop，display problems，and keyboard problems.<br />\r\nDifferent problems will always come up with machines，and they cannot be avoided(避免)．Old machines will always have to be replaced by new ones. However，if we are more careful and handle our laptops with care，they will last for a longer period of time，and they will perform better. This is not a hard thing to do，but it will greatly increase the life and performance of laptops.<br />\r\n40．According to the first paragraph，the laptop is a machine which________.<br />\r\n&nbsp;A．is being used by more and more people in the office<br />\r\n&nbsp;B．will take the place of desktops sooner or later<br />\r\n&nbsp;C．is specially designed for people who like playing computer games<br />\r\n&nbsp;D．can be used for both work and entertainment purposes<br />\r\n41．The underlined word in the first&nbsp; paragraph means &ldquo;________&rdquo;．<br />\r\n&nbsp;A．becoming smaller&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B．becoming more important<br />\r\n&nbsp;C．becoming more popular&nbsp; D．becoming better<br />\r\n42．We infer that graphic designers still use huge display screen laptops most probably because________.<br />\r\n&nbsp;A．huge display screen laptops are very cheap<br />\r\n&nbsp;B．small display screen laptops are not on sale yet<br />\r\n&nbsp;C．they can see their drawings more clearly<br />\r\n&nbsp;D．they also want to play computer games<br />\r\n43．What can we learn from the second paragraph?<br />\r\n&nbsp;A．That laptops can only be used for one year.<br />\r\n&nbsp;B．That laptops are not as good as desktops.<br />\r\n&nbsp;C．That the prices for laptops are too high.<br />\r\n&nbsp;D．That laptops may have problems which cannot be fixed.<br />\r\n<strong>C</strong><br />\r\nThe organizers of the Beijing Olympics have predicted every aspect of the preparatory work and are making every effort to fulfill their task for 2007.<br />\r\n<strong>Competition schedule finalized</strong><br />\r\nThe competition schedule for the 28 sports and 302 events has been settled already. The detailed daily schedule will be made in the final three months before the Olympics，due to the arrangements to be made for TV broadcasters.<br />\r\n<strong>1,000 cultural events expected</strong><br />\r\nBeijing is expected to hold as many as 1,000 Olympics&shy;related cultural activities，including high&shy;level exhibitions and art performances，presentations of foreign art troops，community cultural squares，and promotions by sponsors and co&shy;host cities.<br />\r\n<strong>30,000 journalists to cover the Olympics</strong><br />\r\nMore than 30,000 journalists are expected to come to Beijing during the Games. They pose a great challenge to the organizers in terms of how to meet their specific news coverage demands.<br />\r\n<strong>Two million visitors to test Beijing&rsquo;s services</strong><br />\r\nAt least two million Chinese and half a million foreign tourists are expected to visit Beijing during the Olympics. Taking into account another 50,000 athletes and media，accommodation is a big challenge，too.122 Beijing&shy;based star&shy;class hotels were signed for the purpose in 2006.But how can they make 10,000 rooms available for <u>domestic</u> <u>visitors</u> and 160,000&mdash;180,000 rooms for overseas visitors？The organizers are trying to find solutions to the problem in 2007.<br />\r\n<strong>Hot tickets</strong>，<strong>low prices</strong><br />\r\nIn previous Olympics，one&shy;third of the tickets were hot，another one third were break&shy;even and the remaining one third were unwillingly received. In contrast，most of the Beijing Olympic tickets have been hot，according to the ticketing program so far. The most expensive ticket for the opening ceremony stands only at 5,000 <em>yuan</em>&mdash;the lowest prices seen in recent editions of the Olympics.<br />\r\n44．This passage aims to tell the readers________.<br />\r\n&nbsp;A．the challenges the Beijing Olympics are facing<br />\r\n&nbsp;B．the preparatory work that the organizers are doing<br />\r\n&nbsp;C．the difficulties of organizing the Olympics<br />\r\n&nbsp;D．the information about the Beijing Olympics<br />\r\n45．Which of the following may not be considered when making the daily schedule?<br />\r\n&nbsp;A．The TV broadcasting.<br />\r\n&nbsp;B．The audience&rsquo;s presentation.<br />\r\n&nbsp;C．The weather condition.<br />\r\n&nbsp;D．The athletes&rsquo; competing habits.<br />\r\n46．Which of the following is TRUE according to the text?<br />\r\n&nbsp;A．The cultural activities will be held shortly after the Olympic Games.<br />\r\n&nbsp;B．Some foreign art communities will also give performances in Beijing.<br />\r\n&nbsp;C．The number of journalists coming to the Games will be largest.<br />\r\n&nbsp;D．Cultural activities won&rsquo;t be held in co&shy;host cities.<br />\r\n47．The underlined word &ldquo;domestic visitors&rdquo; (in Paragraph 5) refers to________.<br />\r\n&nbsp;A．visitors with important posts<br />\r\n&nbsp;B．visitors with special purposes<br />\r\n&nbsp;C．visitors from the host country<br />\r\n&nbsp;D．visitors from advanced countries<br />\r\n<strong>D</strong><br />\r\nA punctual person is in the habit of doing a thing at the proper time and is never late in keeping an appointment.<br />\r\nThe unpunctual man, on one hand, never does what he has to do at the proper time. He is always in a hurry and in the end loses both time and his good name. A lost thing may be found again, but lost time can never be regained. Time is more valuable than material things. In fact, time is life itself. The unpunctual man is for ever wasting and mismanaging his most valuable asset (财产) as well as other&rsquo;s. The unpunctual person is always complaining that he finds no time to answer letters, or return calls or keep appointments promptly. But the man who really has a great deal to do is very careful of his time and seldom complains of want of it. He knows that he can not get through his huge amount of work unless he faithfully keeps every piece of work when it has to be attended to.<br />\r\nFailure to be punctual in keeping one&rsquo;s appointments is the sign of disrespect towards others. If a person is invited to dinner and arrives later than the appointed time, he keeps all the other guests waiting for him. Usually this will be regarded as a great disrespect to the host and all other guests present.<br />\r\nUnpunctuality, moreover, is very harmful when it comes to do one&rsquo;s duty, whether public or private. Imagine how it would be if those who are put in charge of important tasks failed to be at their proper place at the appointed time. A man who is known to be habitually unpunctual is never trusted by his friends or fellow men.<br />\r\n48. What does the author think is the main difference between a punctual person and an unpunctual person?<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; A. A punctual person does everything ahead of time while an unpunctual person does everything behind schedule.<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; B. A punctual person does everything at the right time while an unpunctual person seldom does anything at the correct time.<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; C. A punctual person has a lot of appointments while an unpunctual person has few appointments.<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; D. A punctual person has much time to do everything while an unpunctual person has little time to do anything.<br />\r\n49. According to the passage, the main reason that a person is always unpunctual is that _______.<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; A. he has more work to do than other people<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; B. he is always in a hurry when he works<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; C. he doesn&rsquo;t care much about time<br />\r\n&nbsp;&nbsp; D. he always mismanages and wastes his time<br />\r\n50. According to the third paragraph, when you are invited to dinner, you should arrive there _______.<br />\r\n&nbsp; A. after other guests have arrived<br />\r\n&nbsp; B. before all other guests<br />\r\n&nbsp; C. at the appointed time<br />\r\n&nbsp; D. after the host has got things ready<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n<strong>第二节</strong> (共5小题；每小题2分，满分10分)<br />\r\n根据短文内容，从短文后的选项中选出能填入空白处的最佳选项。选项中有两项为多余选项。<br />\r\n<u>51&nbsp; </u>&nbsp;&nbsp;From 18－25, according to I．Q. scores；but you are wiser and more experienced with increasing age.<br />\r\nYou are smartest in your 20&#39;s; around 30, your memory begins to go down, particularly your ability to perform mathematical computations.&nbsp;&nbsp; <u>&nbsp;52</u>__&nbsp;&nbsp; Your vocabulary at the age of 45, for example, is three times as great as when you graduated from college. At 60, your brain possesses almost four times as much information as it did at the age of 21.<br />\r\n__<u>53</u>__ You have the best physical sense of yourself from 15 to 24; the best professional sense from 40 to 49.<br />\r\nBefore the age of 24, we believe that our happiest years are yet to come；over 30，we believe that they are behind us. A National Health survey agrees: after the age of 30, we become more realistic and do not view happiness as a goal in itself. If we maintain our health, achieve professional and emotional goals, happiness, we feel, will follow.<br />\r\n__<u>54</u>__&nbsp;&nbsp; Generally between 30 and 39，but the peak(顶峰) varies with different professions.<br />\r\nMozart wrote a symphony (交响曲)&nbsp; and four sonatas by the age of 8, and Mendelssohn composed his best-known work A Midsummer Night&#39;s Dream, at 17, but most of the great music&nbsp; was written by men between 33 and 39.<br />\r\nThough the peak in most fields comes early, most Nobel Prize winners did their top research in their late 20&#39;s and 30&#39;s&mdash;creative people continue to produce work with high quality throughout their lives&nbsp;&nbsp; __<u>55</u>__<br />\r\nA. When are you most creative (创造性的)?<br />\r\nB. When are you happiest?<br />\r\nC. When are you smartest?<br />\r\nD. Do you know what I.Q. refers to?<br />\r\nE. But your I．Q. for other tasks goes up.<br />\r\nF. Creative people usually produce a lot of works.<br />\r\nG. For the &ldquo;well conditioned mind&rdquo;， there is no upper limit.<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n<strong>卷</strong><strong>II (</strong><strong>共</strong><strong>35</strong><strong>分</strong><strong>)</strong><br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n<strong>IV.</strong><strong>任务型读写（共</strong><strong>10</strong><strong>小题，每小题</strong><strong>1</strong><strong>分，满分</strong><strong>10</strong><strong>分）</strong><br />\r\n认真阅读下列短文，并根据所读内容在文章后表格中的空格里填入一个最恰当的单词。<br />\r\n注意：每个空格只填1个单词。<br />\r\nThe Chinese are very generous when it comes to educating their children. Some parents send their children to the best schools or even abroad to England, the US or Australia, regardless of how much this costs. Many also want their children to take extra-curriculum activities where they either learn a musical instrument or ballet, or other classes that will give them a head start in life. The Chinese believe that the more expensive an education is, the better it is, so parents often spend unreasonable amount of money on education. Even poor couples buy a computer for their son or daughter.<br />\r\nHowever, what most parents fail to see is that the best education they can give<br />\r\ntheir children is usually very cheap. Parents can see that their children&#39;s skills vary; they will usually be skilled in some areas while poor in others. What most parents fail to realize though, is that today&#39;s children lack self-respect and self-confidence.<br />\r\nThe problem is that parents are only educating their children on how to take multiple-choice tests and how to study effectively. They are not teaching them the most important skills they need to be confident, happy and clever.<br />\r\nParents can help achieve this by teaching their children practical skills like cooking, sewing and other housework.<br />\r\nTeaching a child to cook will improve many of the skills that he will need later in life. Cooking demands patience and time. It is an enjoyable but difficult experience. A good cook always tries to improve his cooking, so he will learn to work hard and gradually finish his job successfully. The result, a well--cooked dinner, will give a child a lot of satisfaction and confidence.<br />\r\nAn old machine such as a broken radio or TV set that you give your child as a toy may make him curious and arouse his interest. If he will spend hours looking at it, and try to mend it; your child might become an engineer when he grows up. Such activities do more than teach a child to read a book; but rather they teach them to think, and to use their minds. This is much more important than learning by reading a book.<br />\r\n&nbsp;</span><br />\r\n<table align=\"center\" border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\">\r\n	<tbody>\r\n		<tr>\r\n			<td style=\"width: 132px; She paid the driver and then，using her hands to __<u>1</u>__ the seats，settled in one of them.<br />\r\nIt had been a year since Susan became blind. As the result of an accident she was suddenly thrown into a world of __<u>2</u>__.Susan&#39;s husband Mark watched her __<u>3</u>__ into hopelessness and he was __<u>4</u>__ to use every possible means to help his wife.<br />\r\nFinally，Susan felt ready to __<u>5</u>__ to her job，but how would she get there？She used to take the bus，but she was now too __<u>6</u>__ to get around the city by herself. Mark __<u>7</u>__ to ride the bus with Susan each morning and evening __<u>8</u>__ she could manage it by herself.<br />\r\nFor two weeks，Mark __<u>9</u>__ Susan to and from work each day. He taught her how to rely on her other __<u>10</u>__，specifically her hearing，to determine where she was and how to adapt to her new __<u>11</u>__.<br />\r\nAt last，Susan decided that she was ready to try the trip __<u>12</u>__.Monday morning arrived. Before she left，she hugged her husband __<u>13</u>__，her eyes filled&nbsp; with tears of gratitude(感激)．She said good&shy;bye and，for the first time，they went their __<u>14</u>__ ways. Each day went perfectly，and a wild excitement __<u>15</u>__ Susan. She was doing it!<br />\r\nOn Friday morning，Susan took the bus to work __<u>16</u>__.As she was getting off the bus，the driver said，&ldquo;Miss. I sure __<u>17</u>__ you.&rdquo; Curious，Susan asked the driver __<u>18</u>__.<br />\r\n&ldquo;You know，every morning for the __<u>19</u>__ week，a fine&shy;looking gentleman in a military uniform has been standing across the corner watching you until you enter your office building safely.&rdquo; the bus driver said.<br />\r\nTears of happiness poured down Susan&#39;s cheeks. She was so lucky for he had given her a gift more powerful than __<u>20</u>__.That is the gift of love that can bring light where there is darkness.<br />\r\n1．A.touch&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B．grab&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C．count&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;D．feel<br />\r\n2．A.weakness&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;B．same&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;C．first&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;D．next<br />\r\n20．A.courage&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;B．will&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;C．sight&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D．Wisdom<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n<strong>VIII.</strong><strong>阅读理解（共</strong><strong>5</strong><strong>小题，每小题</strong><strong>2</strong><strong>分，满分</strong><strong>10</strong><strong>分）</strong><br />\r\nPierre is a 25-year-old penguin at the California Academy of Sciences. Due to his old age, he was going bald, which made him feel too cold to swim in the pool. Therefore, biologists at the academy had a wetsuit created for this penguin to help him get back in the swimming pool.<br />\r\nUnlike marine mammals, which have a layer of blubber to keep them warm, penguins depend on their waterproof feathers. Without them, Pierre was unwilling to jump into the swimming pool and ended up<u> trembling</u> on the side of the pool while his 19 peers played in the water.<br />\r\n&quot;He was cold; he would shake,&quot; said Pam Schaller, a senior biologist. Schaller first tried a heat lamp to keep Pierre warm. Then she got another idea: if wetsuits keep humans warm in the cold Pacific, why not make one for Pierre?<br />\r\nSchaller designed the suit, which covered Pierre&rsquo;s body and had small openings for his flippers.<br />\r\n&quot;I would walk behind him and look at where there were any gaps, and cut and refit and cut and refit until it looked like it was extremely suitable,&quot; she said.<br />\r\nOne concern was that the other penguins would reject Pierre in his new suit, but in fact, they accepted his new look. He swam freely and got along with others well, although he was the only penguin with a black stomach.<br />\r\nSchaller couldn&rsquo;t say for sure whether the wetsuit allowed Pierre to recover his fine feathers, but &quot;certainly we were able to keep him comfortable during a period of time that would have been very difficult for him to stay comfortable&quot;.<br />\r\nPierre will take off his suit after his new feathers grow back.<br />\r\n1. Pierre felt too cold to swim in the pool because of _____.<br />\r\n&nbsp; A. not having a layer of blubber&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. having few feathers due to old age<br />\r\n&nbsp; C. having no wetsuit&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. others penguins rejecting him<br />\r\n2. The idea of making a wetsuit for Pierre came from _____.<br />\r\n&nbsp; A. total invention&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. the use of wetsuit on humans<br />\r\n&nbsp; C. the use of heat lamp&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. waterproof feathers<br />\r\n3. Schaller followed Pierre in order to see _____.<br />\r\n&nbsp; A. whether other penguins would reject him&nbsp;&nbsp; B. if anywhere of wetsuit needed to be cut and refit<br />\r\n&nbsp; C. if the wetsuit kept warm&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;D. whether the wetsuit would keep the feathers from recovering<br />\r\n4. What does the underlined word in the second paragraph mean?<br />\r\n&nbsp; A. feeling scared&nbsp;&nbsp; B. staying alone&nbsp;&nbsp; C. shaking with cold&nbsp; D. keeping warm<br />\r\n5. The best title of the passage is _____.<br />\r\n&nbsp; A. Wetsuit for An Old Penguin&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. Old Penguin Getting Bald<br />\r\n&nbsp; C. Unwilling to Swim&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. Strange Look of Pierre<br />\r\n&nbsp;<br />\r\n&nbsp;</span><br />\r\n','','','221.1.213.194');

Here is the__<u>20</u>__I tried.<br />\r\nEach morning during a fifteen&shy;minute bath，I__<u>21</u>__to cultivate (培养) a big，happy smile. I found out，<u> 22</u>__，that it couldn&rsquo;t be a forced smile<u> 23</u> just for the purpose of putting dollars in my<u> 24 </u>.It had to be an honest&shy;to&shy;goodness smile from down deep<u>&nbsp; 25 </u>，an outward expression of happiness from within!<br />\r\n&nbsp; Let&rsquo;s see<u> 26 </u>starting off with a good fifteen&shy;minute workout of the smile muscles<u> 27 </u>me during the day. I also found that it__<u>31</u>__people when I passed them on the street to give them a__<u>32</u>__smile.<br />\r\n&nbsp; Give every living soul you meet the best smile you have__<u>33</u>__smiled in your life，and see how much better you__<u>34</u>__and look. D． bitter<br />\r\n33．A.never&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B．just&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; C．already&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D．ever<br />\r\n34．A.prove&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
